content.title: Amaurosis Fugax
content.definition: Transient monocular vision loss caused by temporary retinal ischemia, typically from emboli originating from the ipsilateral internal carotid artery.

clinical_features.embolic: Platelet-fibrin or cholesterol emboli from carotid plaque
clinical_features.hemodynamic: Flow-limiting ICA stenosis with reduced perfusion pressure
clinical_features.arteritis: Giant cell arteritis affecting ophthalmic circulation
clinical_features.cardiac: Less common, cardiac emboli to ophthalmic artery

clinical_features.onset: Sudden, painless vision loss in one eye
clinical_features.description: Curtain or shade descending over visual field
clinical_features.recovery: Complete recovery, vision returns from periphery
clinical_features.frequency: May be single episode or recurrent

clinical_features.carotid_imaging: Duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA of carotid arteries
clinical_features.ophthalmologic_exam: Fundoscopy may show Hollenhorst plaques (cholesterol emboli)
clinical_features.cardiac: ECG, echocardiography to rule out cardiac source

clinical_features.antiplatelet: Aspirin or clopidogrel for embolic prevention
clinical_features.risk_factor_modification: Statin, blood pressure control, smoking cessation
clinical_features.revascularization: CEA or CAS for significant ipsilateral carotid stenosis
clinical_features.urgent_evaluation: High near-term stroke risk, evaluate within 24-48 hours

clinical_features.stroke_risk: 10-15% risk of stroke within 90 days if untreated
clinical_features.carotid_stenosis_prevalence: Found in 20-30% of patients with amaurosis fugax

sources.reference: Burde RM et al. J Neuroophthalmol. 2009;29:159-165
North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial Collaborators. N Engl J Med. 1991;325:445-453
